div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,489] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, MAY 7, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and train de luxe viâ Brindisi or viâ Marseilles £19 4.11.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,

row.cell: F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. "Orient" will leave Suez about May 18
R.M.S "Orontes" will leave Suez about June 1.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Oruba" will leave Port Said May 7
R.M.S. "Orotava" will leave Port Said May 21

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying the above reduced fares in one direction are allowed abatement of 1/3 off the full fare if return voyage be made within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20% if return voyage be made within 6 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all particulars apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 30-6-906

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL TWIN-SCREW STEAMERS.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES MAY TO OCTOBER.
Port Said to Tilbury £ 12.15.0. and Port Said to Marseilles £ 9.0.0.
Passengers returning by the Line will be granted a rebate of 33% off the full fare i.e. Liverpool to Port Said £ 11.6.8. and Marseilles to Port Said £ 8.0.0.
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, RANGOON. Departure from Suez.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,636 tons, May. 10.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Herefordshire 7,182 tons, May 13.
Agents– Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRÆUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from Suaskin every Wedesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m a steamer leaves Suez for JEDDAH continuing every other week to SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODEIDAH, and ADEN. Intermediate streamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co., 31, James St., Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Menepthah now on the berth, will sail on or about Tuesday, 15 May, to be followed by S.S. Seti.

Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only. Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo.
For particulars apply R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO's LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. MARTABAN 7100 Tons will leave PORT SAID about May 14 for London.
S.S. AMARAPOORA 6600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about May 23 for Liverpool.
S.S. IRRAWADDY 7300 Tons will leave PORT SAID about June 13 for Liverpool
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.
Apply WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: Thos. Cook & Son, (EGYPT), LTD
div.p: HEAD OFFICE: LUDGATE CIRCUS, LONDON.
CHIEF EGYPTIAN OFFICE: — CAIRO, near SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
Alexandria, Port Said, Suez, Luxor, Assouan, and Halfa.
TOURIST AND GENERAL PASSENGER AGENTS, BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their passage, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe ; arrangements can also be made for the collection and fowarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.
CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe.
Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at principal Railway Stations and Landing-places I Europe to assist passengers holding their tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Company leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum.-Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE. Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.- Special Steamers and Dahabeahs forPrivate Parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT; Lowest rates.
Best camp equipment in the country.

First class passengers steamers. Sailing fortnightly from Suez.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.
May 7 S.S. Pyrgos from Antwerp.
May 10 S.S. Fenchurch from Antwerp.
May 13 S.S. Lesbos from Hamburg.

div.p: CAPITAL: L. 2,500,000. RESERVE (ENVIRON) : L. 862,000.
Gouverneur: Sir ELWIN PALMER, K.C.B., K.C.M.G.

Siège Social au Caire, Succursale à Alexandria, Agence à Assiout, Assuoan, Benha, Beni-Suef, Chibin el Kom, Damanhour, Fayoum, Khartoum, Kéneh, Mansourah. Minieh, Port-Said, Suakin, Sohag, Tantah, Zagazig, Mouski (Caire) et Londres (4 et 5, King William Street).

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s'occupe de l'achat et de la vente d'effets sur l'Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-904

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairp will find special through carriages and lagguage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9.30 a.m. and are convoyed directly to Quay alongside steamer.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 9 and 23 May; 6 June, 4 p.m.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 7 and 21 May; 4 and 18 June
Far East Lines.
Departures from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama and Kobé, about 5 March, 3 April, 4 May, 3 June, 4 July, 3 August.
To Suez, Aden and Bombay accelerated service about 8 March, 17 March, 8 April, 8 May, 17 June.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about 17 March, 19 April, 19 May.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi and Bombay about 13 March., 13 April, 13 November, 13 December (Winter Line).
East African Line.
Departures from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa-Bay, and Durban about 5 March., 2 April, 3 May, 2 June, 3 July.2 Aug, 2 Sept, 3 Oct., 2 Nov., 3 Dec.
For information apply to the Agents, Alexandria, Port Said and Suez, Thos. Cook & Son, Ld., Leon Heller, Cairo Agent, 24, Sharia Maghraby, (Telephone 192), Cairo; F. Tedeschi, Helouan.
Special rates for Egyptian officials, members of Army of Occupation and their families.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: A Sleeping Car is attached to the 11.30 p.m train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Entrainment Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Dining and Sleeping Cars are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday, and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday, and Sunday.
Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the Company in Cairo station. 1st clas tickets Cairo-Luxor P.T. 206. Sleeping P.T. 75.

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: CAIRO-KHARTOUM MAIL SERVICE. - SUMMER TIME-TABLE 1906
Commencing from 1st of April, 1906, until further notice.

*Sleeping and Dining Cars. - During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Cars trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays, and Saturdays at 6:30 p.m, and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1906, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Cars will be attached to the ordinary nigh trains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days.

div.head: Egyptian State Railways.
div.p: †Dining Car. §Sleeping Car. First and Second Class only.
* Dining and Sleeping Cars are attached to these trains on the following days: -- From Cairo, every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday. From Luxor, every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.
J. H. l'E. JOHNSTONE, General Manager.

div.head: THE LARGEST STOCK OF
div.p: SURPLUS BOOKS
IN THE WORLD.
OFFERED AT GREATLY REDUCED PRICES.

Every month Mudie's publish a fresh list of their Surplus Books and New Remainders. The list contains popular works on Trave Biography, Art History, Naval and Military Subjects and Fiction, and will be sent post free on application to any part of the world. All the leading English Reviews and Magazines can be supplied, new or second band. Rates on application. Also Baedeker's, Murray's and Black's Guides. Dictionaries in European and Oriental Languages. Maps and Guides. New books at discount prices.
MUDIE'S LIBRARY, LIMITED.
30-34 NEW OXFORD STREET, LONDON, W.C
Medical Invoice Forms in Various Styles
J. Margosches
Engraver & Printer
Bulac Road Cairo

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: NEW VICTORIA HOTEL,
div.p: Open all the year round.
San Stefano, Near Alexandria, Halt No. 2.

Specially built in 1904 for a class Hotel with every modern comfort. Magnificent Dining room, Saloons, Smoking room, largo Verandahs and Garden. Electric light. MODERATE CHARGES. Ten minutes by carriage or Palais tram from Sidi Gaber.—Special terms for Government Officials and Officers of the Army of Occupation. C. F. RAISIG. Manager.
RESTAURANT AND BAR OPEN TO NON-RESIDENTS.

div.head: HOTEL BRISTOL. CAIRO.
div.p: Full South, Electric Light, opposite Esbekieh Gardens, Large Verandahs, Moderate Charges,
CHAS. BAUER, Proprietor.

The Hotel is beautifully fitted up and is in the most central part of Cairo. Terms for pension fare at the rate of ten shillings a day. Special terms for officers of Army of Occupation. 24,882-31-10-5

div.p: DE PARIS.
CAPITAL: 150,000,000 frs,-£ 6,000,000 FULLY PAID UP. — HEAD OFFICE: 14, Rue Bergere, Paris
Alexandria Branch 11, Rue Cherif Pacha.—40 Branches in Paris, and 112 Throughout France.

Branches in London, Liverpool, Manchester, Morocco, Tunis, East India, Madagascar, Australia, etc. Bills Collected. Deposit Accounts opened at sight & for fixed periods, Advances on securities, in current account. Letters of Credit and Telegraphic Transfers Issued. Foreign Exhange Bought and Sold. div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

div.head: DEATH
div.p: McDougel.- On 10th inst., at the Deaconesses' Hospital, ALexandria, after four days' illness, Ducan McDougel, aged 28. Interred at the Protestant Cemetery on 11th inst.

SATURDAY, MAY 12, 1965.

div.head: OUR CONSULS.
div.p: Mr. Ernest William makes some suggestons in "The Standard" for improving our consular system, from the point of view of the commercial world. He would have Consuls placed under the control of the Board of Trade as well as of the Foreign Office, and he would compel them to pass examinations before appointment Consols, he argues, should be mapped out into two divisions—those in which owing to the lack of commerce or the preponderating character of other matters demanding the Consol's attention (such, for example, as certain of the posts in the Near Bast), the Board of Trade would not need to interfere, and the candidate would not need to hold a commercial diploma ; and those in which commerce is of importance. To the former class the Foreign Office coaid appoint, with or without power of veto in the Board of Trade ; to the other the Board of Trade could appoint, with simply power of veto in the Foreign Office.

But the mention of mapping out the world's British consulates calls to mind another reform which is needed. The consular posts themselves need to be rearranged and expended. Is it not, for example, ridiculous to have a Consul at Florence, where neither trade nor Oriental politics nor shipping demands such an officer, and at Milan, one of the chief centres of Italian industry, only a Vice-Consul, who need not be an Englishman, and who, we believe, only gets something like £60 a year, out of which he buys his own stationery. Of course, he can give but a small portion of his time to the important interests of British trade, which the Consul in that city might further. Why, again, should the Riviera possess numerous Consuls, while some important manufacturing towns in the interior of France possess none ? Most flagrant discrepancy of a 1, why should Austria-Hungary, a great and important commercial country, have but seven British Consuls, while little Greece has four teen ? Even in Germany the same thing is seen. The Empire contains but twenty-eight British consular officers ; and Spain has forty eight. All this must be changed. Of course, the Foreign Office mast be allowed to retain its consular representatives in places where here are real diplomatic reasons for a British representative, even though there be no trade, but there are many posts in which there is neither trade nor diplomacy to serve. By striking these off the list the number of commercial Consuls can he increased without increasing the total service.

Even, however, a total increase in the consular service must not be boggled at if good cause can be shown for representation in more places that the present number of Consuls would serve ; and there is one important direction io which a considerable increase in he total number of commercial consular officers is necessary. We refer to the Colonie?. With our Colonies we already do a third of our total foreign trade, and we expect to do with them a large proportion in the future; yet throughout the Daughter States of the Empire there is not a single Government official analogous to a Consul. It seems absurd ; yet, of course, one hw only to think what a Consul is—the representative of Great Britain in a foreign country- to see how it has come about that we have no Consuls in the Colonies. Consols so called, and fulfilling some of the functions of Consuls, we most continue to do without; but that is no reason why we should not have commercial Consuls, and thus is every reason why we should have plentiful supply of them. One obvious reason is that foreign Powers have their Consols in our Colonies busy furthering the trade of their respective nationalities, and as for practical purposes of business Australia and Canada are to us as much foreign markets as Japan or the United States, our trade suffers so long as the mannfactnrers of the Mother-country are not represented by Government officials in the Daughter States.

It is also suggested—and we are quoting now from proposal's made by consular officers themselves, who have given study to the question— that an inspector of Consuls should be appointed to visit the Consuls periodically and remove inefficient officers from their posts. This proposal is, we believe, to be embodied in the American reform.

We must find room in conclusion for one more reform. Consular officers should in all cases be in every sense Englishmen. Without casting any reflection upon the gentlemen serving as British Consols who are natives of the country to which they are appointed, it is obvious that their national ties most create some bias in favour of their own country—sufficient to mitigate their devotion to British trade; and it is noteworthy that one of the objects sought in the present reconstruction of the American consular service is the supersession of foreigners by Americans, to be obtained through such increase in remuneration as will permit Americans to fill the post It would pay us to follow America's example.

div.head: "INVESTMENTS."
div.p:
"Investments" introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them"; "Theory of Successful Speculation"; "How to start an Account" ; "The Advantages of 'Call Options'"; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities" ; "How to Invest in Mines"; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments" ; "General Principles for Investors" ; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Principles for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities."
"Investments" (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning "Egyptian Gazette."
LONDON & PARIS EXCHANGE LIMITED, GENERAL BANKERS. BASILDON HOUSE, BANK, LONDON, E.C.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Tries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, mercredi 9 Mai.

Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres vient d'être élevé à 4 pour cent Hier, au stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais est remonté de 1/4, après avoir perdu 3/8 la veille. L'Unifiée, la National Bank, l'Agricole et la Daïra sont encore restées invariées à leurs cours précédents. La Delta Light a regagné 1/8 5 12 3/8
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a clôturé a 779. soit en nouvelle hausse de 4 francs. La Banque d'Athènes est demeurée inchangée à 150.

Notre marché des valeurs a été, ce matin encore, inactif et lourd; avec une petite accentuation de la tendance à la dépression. A peu d'exceptions près, les titres ont payé, plus ou moins, leur tribut à la réaction.

Les optimistes prédisent avec assurance la fin de cette série de mauvaises séances. Ils se basent, paraît-il, d'un côté sur la conviction que le resserrement monétaire a Londres aurait atteint son apogée ; de l'autre côté sur l'espoir que le différend turco-anglais serait certainement appelé à recevoir une solution pacifique a l'approche de l'expiration de l'ultimatum.

La National Bank est restée délaissée 5 26 9/32. L'Agricole a faibli à 9 7/8. Le Comptoir Financier a été inscrit 5 6 1/4, ex-right ; l'action nouvelle a été cotée £6. La Cassa di Sconto a rétrogradé a 215 et la nouvelle émission 5 212 ; la Banque d'Athènes a 148 et la Banque d'Orient à 136. La Banque d'Abyssinie s'est réveillée 5 6 1/2.

L'action Crédit Foncier est restée immobile 5 780. La Nile Land a avancé 5 16 9/16 pour fléchir en clôture 5 16 3/8 vendeurs. Il se confirme que l'achat du restant da domaine de Kasr-el-Doubara rencontre des obstacles sérieux.

L'Immobilière a faibli a 366; la part de fondateur a 615. L'Agricole du Nil est également revenue a 273; la part de fondateur a 8 3/8. L'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux est restée a 4 1/4 ; la part de fondateur a 78.
La Brasserie des Pyramides a fléchi a 133 et la part de dividende 5 63.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich ont été traités a 17 7/16 et les Baehler a 5 L'Anglo-American s'est raffermi a 5 1/2.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta ont ete ramenés a 4 3/16 ; les Egyptian Constructions: 5 15/16; les Glymenopoulo a 1 1/2 et les Abdy a 1 5/16-8/8.

La Société des Exceleior Hotels vient de conclure l'achat des terrains contigus a ceux qu'elle possédait déjà au rond-point Soliman-Pacha. Bile dispose donc actuellement d'environ 5,500 mètres carrés de terrain, dont une partie pourra être revendue dans des conditions très avantageuses.

M. Dattari, le cédant du premier lot acheté par le syndicat qui a constitué la Société, a réclamé le paiement immédiat du solde qui lui était dû sur ce terrain. Bien qu'au dire du contentieux de la Société, cette réclamation fût mal fondée, on a pris les mesures nécessaires pour le règlement de cette somme. Les tribunaux auront a se prononcer sur les dommages que la Société estime lui avoir été causés de ce chef.
Un second versement de L.E. 1 par action sera probablement appelé vers le 15 Juin proohain.
On rapporte que l'émission de la Commercial, Industrial and Land Co. of Egypt a été largement ouverte.
On ajoute que la Société serait en négocia­tions pour la conclusion de deux ou trois nouvelles affaires très promettantes.
L'assemblée générale ordinaire des actionnaires de la Nungovich Hotels Co. est convoquée pour le jeudi 31 Mai courant, 5 4 h. p.m., au siège social au Caire.
A l'ordre du jour : rapport du conseil; présentation des comptes de l'exercice 1905, fixation da dividende, élection d'administrateurs, etc.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

— Les détenteurs d'actions et parts de fondateur de la Land Bank of Egypt sont informés que les dividendes de £0.7.6 par action an­cienne, de P.E. 6,75 par action nouvelle et de £ 1.2 eh. par part de fondateur sont payables 5 partir du 15 du courant, 5 Alexandrie, contre présentation du coupon No 1.
— Un avis de la Nungovieh Hotels Co. porte que le second versement de £ 4 sur les actions nouvelles peut être effectué le 30 Mai courant, au lieu de la date précédemment
prescrite du 15 Mai.

div.head: Royal Insurance Company.
div.p: NOTICE,

Messrs. Haselden and Co., Egyptian Agents for the Royal Insurance Company of Liverpool, hereby beg to inform their clients that having regard to the widespread uneasiness which the San Francisco disaster has created in the minds of the public generally, the Directors of the Royal Insurance Company have made the following official announcement:—
" The Royal Insurance Company has
" learnt by cablegram from its Manager at
" San Francisco that the area of the recent
" disaster involves a possible liability of
" £1,350,000 (6,750,000dols.). Having regard
" however to the large balance at the credit
" of Profit and Loss at the end of 1904, and
" the profitable results of last year's opera-
" tions, the payments which will have to be
" made in connection wit,h this liability will
" not necessitate any reduction in the Fire
" and Reserve Funds of the Compary."

It is anticipated that when the Manager of the Company at San Francisco has been able to look closely into the position it will transpire that the Company's losses will be appreciably less than the figure mentioned. 27888-4-1
